audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 23, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Books for Unit 22 and Unit 23.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Sam Kent’s Journal.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the suffixes -er and -or, let’s blend some words using these suffixes and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/rrrēēēd/, read. /rrrēēēdûûûrrr/, reader. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Suffixes "er" and "or." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
Listen as I read the following word: "play." Add the suffix "er" to the end of "play." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "play" across from the phonics/syllable card "er" and the word "player" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Player. <pause> The suffix "er" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.” A player is “a person who plays something.”
Listen as I read the following word: "act." Add the suffix "or" to the end of "act." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "act" across from the phonics/syllable card "or" and the word "actor" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Actor. <pause> The suffix "or" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.” An actor is a person who acts.
Practice adding suffixes "er" or "or" to the following words and see how many new words you can make.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards "er" and "or" and the following word cards: teach, read, help, sail, invent, collect>

audio.transcription: Now write "er" and "or" multiple times as you say the sounds for each.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about rocks and minerals. First, look at these six pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. sedimentary rock <pause>, metamorphic rock <pause>, igneous rocks <pause>, gems <pause>, calcium <pause>, potassium. Look at the picture of potassium. What colors do you see?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about rocks and minerals. The word is essential. Essential means “necessary or important to have.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, essential>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words essential and solid>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Earth’s Essential Elements”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about rocks and minerals? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 23 Student Book. The title of this story is "Renata the Rock Star.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Renata the Rock Star. This fictional, or made-up, story is about a girl who collects and paints rocks.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: intend. Intend means to plan on doing something. The children intend to do their homework after they have a snack. What do you intend to do this weekend?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, intend>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the phrase in the first paragraph that describes Renata.
What does Renata intend to do with the rocks after she paints them? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Which word describes Renata: selfish or giving? Explain.
What can you do to make someone smile today?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write how the walkers, hikers, and bike riders will most likely react to Renata’s rocks. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Initial, Medial, and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 23, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 23.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Renata the Rock Star.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: area, ever, hours, measure, notice.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word measure. Say the word with me. Measure. What syllables do you hear in measure? Let’s clap the syllables as we say the word slowly: mea-sure. The last syllable is spelled sure. That’s a common ending syllable in words like treasure and pleasure, so it’s good to emember this spelling.
Spell the word with me: m-e-a-s-u-r-e. The word "measure" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: area, ever, hours, measure, notice.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Initial, Medial, and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: tray
Say the word tray, but change the beginning sound. Change /t/, to /g/. What's the new word? <pause> gray
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: send
Say the word send, but change the ending sound. Change /d/, to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> sent
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the middle sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: man
Audio: Say the word man, but change the middle sound. Change /a/, to /ē/. What's the new word? <pause> mean
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about soil. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. grass <pause>, organic layer <pause>, topsoil <pause>, subsoil <pause>, bedrock. Look at the subsoil and bedrock in the picture. What do you notice about them?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about soil. The word is layers. Layers means “things that lie above or under other things.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, layers>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words layers and vital>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “What’s the “Dirt” on Soil?”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about soil? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review suffixes "er" and "or." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
Listen as I read the following word: "paint." Add the suffix "er" to the end of "paint." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "paint" across from the phonics/syllable card "er" and the word "painter" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Painter. <pause> The suffix "er" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.” A painter is “a person who paints.”
Listen as I read the following word: "sail." Add the suffix "or" to the end of "sail" What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "sail" across from the phonics/syllable card "or" and the word "sailor" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Sailor. <pause> The suffix "or" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.” A sailor is a person who sails.
Practice adding suffixes "er" or "or" to the following words and see how many new words you can make.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards "er" and "or" and the following word cards: fight, write, read, lead, invent, bank>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the suffixes -er and -or, let’s blend some words using these suffixes and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/rrrēēēd/, read. /rrrēēēdûûûrrr/, reader. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.' Say the word nice and loud.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 23 Student Book. The title of this text is "The Soil Doctor.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The Soil Doctor. This comic is about soil and people who work with soil. The narrator is Gregor, a gopher, and his words are in speech bubbles.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: mixture. Mixture is something made of smaller parts that are now “mixed” together. I helped Dad pour the mixture of yogurt and berries into the bowls. A jar of coins can have a mixture of quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, mixture>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word in the title that has an -or ending.
What is dirt a mixture of? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why do Doctor Lee and Farmer Johnson work together? Explain.
Do you think soil is gross or interesting? Why?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: List what Doctor Lee learned about Farmer Johnson’s soil. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 23, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 23.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Soil Doctor.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review suffixes "er" and "or." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
Listen as I read the following word: "sing." Add the suffix "er" to the end of "sing." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "sing" across from the phonics/syllable card "er" and the word "singer" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Singer. <pause> The suffix "er" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.” A singer is “a person who sings.”
Listen as I read the following word: "collect." Add the suffix "or" to the end of "collect" What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "collect" across from the phonics/syllable card "or" and the word "collector" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Collector. <pause> The suffix "or" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.” A collector is a person who collects something.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the suffixes -er and -or, let’s blend some words using these suffixes and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with -er.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with -or.
Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word sail. <pause> Add -or to the end. What word did you make? Sailor
Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word sail <pause>. Now change sail to sailor. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words that end with -er and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words that end with -er. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word container. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word container>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: actor/director, pitcher/catcher.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs actor/director, pitcher/catcher>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 23, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 23.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: order, piece, short, today, true>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word today. Say the word with me. Today. The word "today" has two parts: to-day We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me: t-o-d-a-y.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: order, piece, short, true.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word worker.
Now write the word actor.
Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
survivor
speaker
builder
visitor
stranger

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review suffixes "er" and "or." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "or">

audio.transcription: The suffixes "er" and "or" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.”
Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 23 Student Book. The title of this text is "Riddle Me This!" Point to each word as you read the title with me: Riddle Me This! These are riddles. Each riddle contains clues about a noun. You will identify the word. Read the riddles. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the riddles with suffixes -er and -or and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.

The first sentence is: The diners notice that the waiter is very busy. Say the sentence with me: The diners notice that the waiter is very busy. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.

The second sentence is: The narrator tells the story of a great warrior. Say the sentence with me: The narrator tells the story of a great warrior. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.
Let's review suffixes. Suffixes "er" and "or" are added to some verbs to form nouns. These suffixes can mean “a person who” or “something that does.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "or">

audio.transcription: Some base words require spelling changes before adding suffixes, such as dropping the final "e" or doubling the final consonant.
Listen as I read the following word: drum. Before adding the suffix "er" to "drum," we need to double the final consonant "m."
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: drum drum+m+er drummer (show "er" in red font)

audio.transcription: Now let's add suffix "er" to the end of the word "drum." What is the new word?
drummer. <pause> A drummer is “a person who plays the drums.”
Listen as I read the following word: create. Before adding the suffix "or" to "create," we need to drop the final "e."
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: create create-e+or creator (show "or" in red font) >

audio.transcription: Now let's add suffix "or" to the end of the word "create." What is the new word?
creator. <pause> A creator is “someone who creates.”
Practice adding suffixes "er" or "or" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words across from the following phonics/syllable cards: win (er card), senate (or card), grow (er card), educate (or card)>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 23, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 23.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Riddle Me This!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about soil and sand. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. garden <pause>, pot <pause>, plant <pause>, soil <pause>, ocean <pause>, beach <pause>, sandcastle <pause>, sand. Look at the sand in the picture. What can you do with sand?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about soil and sand. The word is common. Common means “widespread or used by many people.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, common>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words common and plunge>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Getting to Know Soil and Sand.”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about soil and sand? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.
Let's review suffixes. Suffixes "er" and "or" are added to some verbs to form nouns. These suffixes can mean “a person who” or “something that does.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "or">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "ride." Before adding the suffix "er" to ride, we need to drop the final "e." Now let's add suffix "er" to the end of the word. What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: ride ride-e+er rider (show "er" in red font) >

audio.transcription: rider. <pause> A rider is “someone who rides.”
Now let's add suffix "or" to the end of the word "conduct." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "conduct" using letter cards and the phonics/syllable card for "or">

audio.transcription: conductor. <pause> A conductor is “someone who conducts.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "conduct" using letter cards and the phonics/syllable card for "or", under them, show the word "conductor">

audio.transcription: Practice adding suffixes "er" or "or" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words across from the following phonics/syllable cards: sing (er card), survive (or card), jog (er card), elevate (or card)>

audio.transcription: Look at these words. Let's read the words together: director, editor, offi cer, tailor, leader, janitor, painter, manager, doctor, builder, aviator, soldier. Now look at these two categories. This is the word director. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put director under? <pause> Yes, director goes in the -er category because the word director ends with -er. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show words director, editor, offi cer, tailor, leader, janitor, painter, manager, doctor, builder, aviator, soldier> <visual: show word director> <visual: show the sorting cards er and or in a pocket chart>

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
"-er" and "-or" are common word parts. You may notice the -er word part in many words. As we read, let's look for words with -er and -or.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 23 Student Book. The title of this text is "Let's Make a Terrarium.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Let's Make a Terrarium. You will read a procedural text about how to make a terrarium, which is a small habitat for plants and/or animals.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: sufficient. Sufficient means enough. Three pizzas are sufficient for the birthday party. How do you know if a plant has received a sufficient amount of water?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, sufficient>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word in the first sentence that has a suffix.
How can you tell that the terrarium has a sufficient amount of soil? Find the sentence that answers this question.
How does the diagram help you understand the directions? Explain.
Would you like to make your own terrarium?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw four boxes on a sheet of paper. <pause> Write one key step for building a terrarium in each box. Use these steps to write a one or two sentence summary of the text. <pause> Share your summary with a partner before writing.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 23, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 23.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Let’s Make a Terrarium.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Listen as I say a word: and
Say the word and, but change /d/ to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> ant
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the second sound in a word. Listen as I say a word: clue
Say the word clue, but change /l/ to /r/. What's the new word? <pause> crew
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review suffixes "er" and "or." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
Listen as I read the following word: "play." Add the suffix "er" to the end of "play." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "play" across from the phonics/syllable card "er" and the word "player" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Player. <pause> The suffix "er" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.” A player is “a person who plays something.”
Listen as I read the following word: "act." Add the suffix "or" to the end of "act." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "act" across from the phonics/syllable card "or" and the word "actor" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Actor. <pause> The suffix "or" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.” An actor is a person who acts.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: area, ever, hours, measure, notice, order, piece, short, today, true.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word area. Say the word with me: "area"
Spell the word with me: a-r-e-a. The word "area" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: area, ever, hours, measure, notice, order, piece, short, today, true.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with suffixes -er or -or and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with suffixes -er or -or. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word dancer. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word dancer>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: washer/dryer, tutor/ruler.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs washer/dryer, tutor/ruler>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 23, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 23.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. area, <pause> ever, <pause> hours, <pause> measure, <pause> notice, <pause> order, <pause> piece, <pause> short, <pause> today, <pause> true.
audio.notes: <visual: show "area, ever, hours, measure, notice, order, piece, short, today, true" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.

Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "I can use a ______ to a measure ______ ." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "I can use a [blank] to measure [blank]." Then show "area, ever, hours, measure, notice, order, piece, short, today, true" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for 2nd word>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 23 Student Book. The title of this text is "Beach Day!" Point to the word as you read the title with me: Beach Day! This text is about preparing for a beach day and includes a list.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing the list?
Write a list of the supplies you use in school every day.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review suffixes "er" and "or." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
The suffixes "er" and "or" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.”
Listen as I read the following word: "act." Add the suffix "or" to the end of "act." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "act" across from the phonics/syllable card "or" and the word "actor" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Actor.
Practice by adding the suffix "er" to the word "play."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "play" across from the phonics/syllable card "er">

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: area, ever, hours, measure, notice, order, piece, short, today, true.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word ever. Say the word with me: "ever"
Spell the word with me: e-v-e-r. The word "ever" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: area, ever, hours, measure, notice, order, piece, short, today, true.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 23, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 23.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Beach Day!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Listen as I read the following word: "wound." (/woond/) When "wound" is pronounced this way, it is a noun that means “an injury.”
Now listen as I read the following word: "wound." When "wound" is pronounced this way, it means the past tense of the verb wind (/wind/).

"wound" and "wound" are homographs. The words are spelled the same but have different pronunciations and meanings. In a text, the context—or words near the homograph—gives readers clues about which meaning of the word the author intends.
Listen as I read the following word: "bow." When "bow" is pronounced this way, it is a noun that means a knot tied with two loops and two loose ends.
Now listen as I read the following word: "bow." When "bow" is pronounced this way, it is a verb meaning to bend the head, body, or knee.
Can you think of any other homographs?
audio.notes: <visual: show the sentence: Can you think of any other homographs?>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review suffixes "er" and "or." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
The suffixes "er" and "or" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.”
Listen as I read the following word: "play." Add the suffix "er" to the end of "play." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "play" across from the phonics/syllable card "er" and the word "player" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Player.
Practice by adding the suffix "or" to the word "act."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "act" across from the phonics/syllable card "or">

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with suffixes.
Now, let's put a box around all the words that are homographs.

Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word sing. <pause> Add -er to the end. What wo rd did you make? Singer. What does this new word mean?
Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word sing <pause>. Now change sing to singer. Which sound is different? Which letters will be different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about how sand is made. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. rock <pause>, hoodoo <pause>, sky <pause>, canyon. Look at the rock in the picture. What different things do you notice about the rock?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about how sand is made. The word is process. Process means “a series of actions or steps.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, process>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words process and extend>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “The “Life Cycle' of Sand.”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about how sand is made? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 23 Student Book. The title of this story is "Our Sandcastles.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Our Sandcastles. You will read a story about a girl going to the beach with her sister and grandma.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: demolished. Demolished is destroyed. The old library was demolished after the new library was built. Have you ever seen a building get demolished? If so, what happened?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, demolished>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that names the grandmother’s job.
What demolished the sandcastle? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How are the narrator and the narrator’s sister alike? How are they different?
Would you rebuild the sandcastle after it was destroyed? Why or why not?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw a picture to remember the important details in the story. Label the details, such as beach, sandpiper, sandcastle, and wave. <pause> Use the drawing to retell the story to a partner. <pause> Then, write your retelling.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 23, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 23.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Our Sandcastles.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review suffixes "er" and "or." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
The suffixes "er" and "or" can mean “a person who” or “something that does.”
Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word banker.
Now write the word janitor.
Finally, write this sentence: We will order a new monitor for our computer.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about erosion shaping land. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Grand Canyon <pause>, river <pause>, The Wave <pause>, ridge <pause>, sandstone. Look at the sandstone in the picture. What do you notice about it?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about erosion shaping land. The word is gradually. Gradually means “happening little by little or slowly over a long period of time.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, gradually>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words gradually and deposit>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Shaping the Land in Amazing Ways.”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about erosion shaping land? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 23 Student Book. The title of this text is "Mudslide.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Mudslide. This text is an interview about a recent mudslide. In the interview, a reporter asks questions and two people answer them.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: primary. Primary means most important. Molly’s primary reason for becoming a veterinarian is her love of animals. What do you think is the primary way we can protect, or keep safe, Earth’s environment?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, primary>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that tells who is asking the questions in this text.
According to Will, what is the primary cause of the mudslide? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why does the reporter interview James and Will about the mudslide? Explain.
What are some ways that people can help others who are affected by natural disasters?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write an interview between the reporter and the governor. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before writing.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 23, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 23.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Mudslide.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
Write dream.
Add a suffix to dream to name someone who dreams.
Change dreamer to name someone who trains animals.
Change trainer to name someone who walks.
Add a suffix to dream to name someone who dreams.
Change surfer to name someone who helps.
Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 23!

Let's review homographs. Homographs are words that are spelled the same but have different pronunciations and meanings. The words "pruh-duce" – which means to make something – and "pro-duce" which is something that is grown – are examples of homographs.
Identify two meanings and pronunciations for the following homographs.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: area, ever, hours, measure, notice, order, piece, short, today, true>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "hours."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: hours>

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: day
Say the word day, but change the beginning sound. Change /d/, to /p/. What's the new word? <pause> pay
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: send
Say the word send, but change the ending sound. Change /d/, to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> sent
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the middle sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: ran
Say the word ran, but change the middle sound. Change /a/, to /ā/. What's the new word? <pause> rain
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
